Five-Year Accident History

Howard Station had no RMP-regulated substance released during the past five years.

Emergency Response Program Information

The facility maintains a written emergency action plan, to help protect employees and public welfare as well as the environment. The plan identifies steps to be taken in case of an accidental release, including first aid and medical treatment for exposures; evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation; notification of local emergency response agencies; and notification of the public if a release occurs.

Texon has around-the-clock communications capability, including deployment of emergency response personnel and equipment with appropriate emergency response organizations (fire department, police, sheriff's office, or similar). This interface provides the means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick responses to an incident. In addition, Texon conducts regularly scheduled emergency drills and annual refresher training for facility personnel.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Texon's management is committed to the following:
•	Preventing accidents
•	Training employees in correct response procedures in the event of an accident
•	Participating in community emergency preparedness training

The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop recommendations to prevent future occurrences and forward these results to facility management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the investigation team’s findings and recommendations are tracked until they are concluded. The ultimate resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented and investigation reports are retained for at least five years.

Compliance Audits

According to 40 CFR §68.79(a), Texon is required to conduct an audit every 3 years of the covered procedure to assess compliance with the requirements of the prevention program. The audit must involve at least one individual who is knowledgeable about the process. Good engineering practices are conducted by Texon employees and management, or a qualified third-party, if appropriate. This audit team develops findings that are forwarded to facility management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the audit team's findings are tracked until they are concluded. The ultimate resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent audit reports are retained.

Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Texon's accident release prevention and response policies are applied to the entire RMP-covered process through universal prevention activities, including but not limited to: elimination of sources of ignition, absence of secondary containment or drains for liquid releases, avoidance of congested areas, and atmosphere control. Collectively, these prevention program activities help avoid potential accident scenarios that could be caused by equipment failures and human errors.

Specialized Safety Features

Facility-specific detection and equipment (safety features) are deployed throughout the facility to:

Written procedures provide that work is performed consistently and serve as a basis for training. Examinations and tests are performed to help verify that equipment functions as intended, and that equipment is within acceptable limits. If a deficiency is identified and the situation presents an immediate welfare concern, the deficiency is corrected before placing the equipment back into service. The management team reviews the use of the equipment and determines what further action is necessary.

An integral part of the integrity program is quality assurance. Texon incorporates quality assurance measures into equipment purchases and repairs. This helps to determine that new equipment is applicable for its intended use and that the proper materials and spare parts are used when repairs are made.

Safe Work Practices

Texon has standing safe work practices as mandated by OSHA, EPA, industrial standards, and good engineering practices in place to help provide employee, public, and process safety.

Management of Change

Texon has a comprehensive system to manage changes to facility processes. This system requires that changes to items such as process equipment, chemicals, technology, and procedures be properly reviewed and authorized before being implemented. Each proposed change must be reviewed to:
•	Determine that adequate equipment is in place to manage new hazards 
•	Verify that existing equipment has not been compromised by the proposed change

Affected chemical hazard information, process operating limits, and equipment information and procedures are updated to incorporate these changes. In addition, operating and maintenance personnel are trained on the changes.

Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)

Texon conducts a PSSR for new facility modifications that requires a change in the process safety information. The purpose of the PSSR is to see that safety features, procedures, personnel, and equipment are appropriately prepared for a startup before placing the equipment into service. This review provides one additional check that construction is in compliance with the design specifications and that supporting systems are ready. A PSSR involves field verification of the construction and serves as quality assurance verification that the accident prevention program requirements are properly implemented.

Mechanical Integrity

Texon has established practices and procedures for the secure operation of fixed, rotating, and emergency shutdown equipment. The basic aspects of the program include, but are not limited to, the following:
•	Conducting training
•	Developing written procedures
•	Performing examinations and tests
•	Correcting identified deficiencies
•	Applying quality assurance measures

These activities form a system to maintain process integrity. Maintenance personnel receiv

y operations as mandated by the Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), good engineering practice, and manufacturers. These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. Procedures are continuously reviewed and annually certified by management for completeness and accuracy. Operating procedures are revised, as necessary, by employee suggestions, compliance audits, PHAs, good engineering practice, and pre-startup safety reviews (PSSR), to maintain completeness and accuracy. Revisions are implemented through Texon management.

Process operating procedures are readily available for personnel to use, as necessary, to safely perform their job tasks and maintain the process unit operations within the defined limits.

Training

Texon has implemented a comprehensive training program for employees involved in operating covered processes at the facility. New employees receive basic training in process operations if they are not already familiar with such operations. After completing this training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to learn process-specific duties and tasks. A performance review must be concluded during this training interval. After the operator demonstrates adequate knowledge to perform the duties and tasks safely on their own, they are allowed to work independently. In addition, operators continuously receive subsequent training on the operating procedures to refresh their skills and knowledge to an acceptable level. This refresher training is conducted regularly for at least three years, or more frequently, if deemed necessary. Training is documented for each operator, including the means used to verify and demonstrate skills.

Contractors

For regulated process areas, Texon has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters such as temperatures, levels, and composition in the operators' procedures manual. The facility maintains the process within these limits by using process equipment and monitoring instruments, trained personnel, and protective instrument systems such as automated shutdown systems.

The facility also maintains numerous technical documents with information about the design and construction of the process equipment including materials of construction, design pressures, temperature, and electrical ratings. The design and construction information of the process equipment, in combination with procedures and equipment operating history, provide a basis for inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes. Process safety information must be readily accessible to workers and contractors.

Process Hazard Analysis

Texon has a comprehensive program, including a team of personnel, to identify and manage hazards associated with the RMP-covered process. This program systematically examines potential hazards and puts equipment in place to manage hazards. The team identifies, evaluates, and makes recommendations for the management of identified potential hazards. The team's findings are forwarded to Texon's Management for resolution. The approved mitigation options in response to the PHA team's findings are tracked until completion. The ultimate resolution of each finding is documented and retained.

The facility continuously updates and revalidates the hazard analysis results. These continuous reviews are conducted regularly for at least five years and will be conducted at this frequency until the process is no longer operating. The results and findings from these updates are documented and retained.

Operating Procedures

Texon maintains written Operating Procedures for the covered process that address primar

ses, flammable cryogenic materials, and any liquid or gaseous material that is liquid while under pressure and has a flash point below 73 degrees Fahrenheit [°F] (22.8 degrees Celsius [°C]) and a boiling point below 100 °F (37.8 °C). The covered process for the mixture of flammable substances is calculated in the worst-case scenario that involves the flammable mixture substances above the threshold quantities, greater than 10,000 pounds.

Toxics were not modeled as part of this analysis because the only materials present are i-Butane, n-Butane, i-Pentane, and n-Pentane, which are not classified as toxic substances.

The technical documents referenced above are included in the Process Safety Information portion of the PSM.

Accident Release Prevention and Response Policies

Texon LP (Texon) owns and operates the Howard Station storage facility (facility) in Howard County, Texas. The facility is designed to receive and store butane for delivery to end markets.

Texon has a long-standing commitment to workers and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by efforts in accident prevention, such as training personnel, quality assurance, and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of Texon facilities. Texon policy is to implement reasonable jurisdictions to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, facility-trained personnel plan to evaluate the situation, take actions within the capabilities of the facility, and notify the necessary outside agencies.

Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

Butanes are unloaded from trucks into two (2) 90,000 gallons butane storage bullet tanks prior to injection into a nearby pipeline prior to sales. The two butane storage bullet tanks and connected pipelines are considered a single process that has two or more connected vessels of the same regulated substance that could be involved in a potential release at the facility. Regulated flammable substances (listed in the 40 CFR §68.130) used at the facility are i-Butane, n-Butane, i-Pentane, and n-Pentane. Since there are different flammable substances in a single process, this is defined as a flammable mixture. The RMP rule only applies to flammable mixtures if the amount of a regulated substance in the mixture is greater than 1 percent (1%) and the mixture as a whole meets the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA-4) requirements of “materials that vaporize quickly or completely when subjected to normal atmospheric pressure and temperature, are easily dispersed in the air, and burn easily”.
